text:
>> NARRATOR: Meet the vegetarian that’s
inspiring a new generation of biofuel—
the panda.

Pandas nosh on about 30 pounds of bamboo each
day,

which means they’re experts at digesting
the tough cellulose
that makes up plant cell walls.

Researchers are enlisting pandas in their
efforts to break down cellulose

in renewable plants like switchgrass and sugarcane
to make biofuel.
Their plan?
Studying panda poop.

It turns out that symbiotic bacteria living
in pandas’ digestive tracts
make cellulose-busting enzymes called cellulases.

To get hold of these bacteria, researchers
at the Memphis Zoo grab pellets of poop
from pandas Ya Ya and Le Le.

Then they grind up the poop and sequence the
billions of DNA base pairs in the sample

to profile the gut bacteria and the enzymes
they make.

Out of the hundreds of different bacteria
that live in pandas,

the researchers have found 17 that break down
cellulose.

Other researchers are reaching into the rumen
of cows

to find the bacteria that help them grind
up grass.

And they’re mining the microbes of the leaf
eating hoatzin.

In all these gutsy studies, supercomputers
speed up the search for microbial genes that
encode cellulases.

By cutting and pasting these genes into microorganisms
like E. coli,

researchers hope to bioengineer better ways
to turn plants into sugars.

These sugars can be fermented to make biodiesel
or biogas—
and maybe even power future trips to the zoo.
